action.action-desc: Mr. Foster (for himself and Mr. Cramer) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To require the Secretary of the Treasury to mint coins in commemoration of the 400th anniversary of arrival of the Pilgrims.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Mayflower Commemorative Coin Act.

paragraph.text: The arrival of the Pilgrims at Plymouth, Massachusetts, in 1620 has major significance in the history of the United States.
The Mayflower Compact laid the foundation and moral framework for the future laws of the United States.
The General Society of Mayflower Decedents’ mission is—

subparagraph.text: to tell the story of the Pilgrim's journey on the Mayflower in 1620, bringing with them principles of civil and religious liberty to America as memorialized in the Mayflower Compact;
to raise public awareness and increase the public understanding of the importance of the Pilgrim’s lives and legacies; and
to encourage a passion for history.

paragraph.text: A commemorative coin will bring national and international attention to the lasting legacy of this important event.
The proceeds from a surcharge on the sale of such commemorative coin will assist the financing of educational, scholarship, and outreach programs;

subsection.text: The Secretary of the Treasury (hereafter in this Act referred to as the Secretary) shall mint and issue the following coins:

paragraph.text: Not more than 50,000 $5 coins, which shall—

subparagraph.text: have a diameter of 0.850 inches; and
contain 90 percent gold and 10 percent alloy.

paragraph.text: Not more than 100,000 $1 coins, which shall—

subparagraph.text: have a diameter of 1.500 inches; and

subsection.text: The coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender, as provided in section 5103 of title 31, United States Code.
For purposes of section 5134 of title 31, United States Code, all coins minted under this Act shall be considered to be numismatic items.

paragraph.text: The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the arrival of the Pilgrims.
On each coin minted under this Act there shall be—

subparagraph.text: a designation of the value of the coin;
inscriptions of the words Liberty, In God We Trust, United States of America, and E Pluribus Unum.

subsection.text: The design for the coins minted under this Act shall be—

paragraph.text: selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the General Society of Mayflower Descendants; and
reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee.

subsection.text: Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in proof quality and uncirculated quality.
Only 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins minted under this Act.
The Secretary may issue coins, to the public, minted under this Act only during the 1-year period beginning on January 1, 2020.
The coins issued under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the sum of—

paragraph.text: the face value of the coins;
the surcharge provided in section 7(a) with respect to such coins; and
the cost of designing and issuing the coins (including labor, materials, dies, use of machinery, overhead expenses, marketing, and shipping).

subsection.text: The Secretary shall make bulk sales of the coins issued under this Act at a reasonable discount.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall accept prepaid orders for the coins minted under this Act before the issuance of such coins.
Sale prices with respect to prepaid orders under paragraph (1) shall be at a reasonable discount.

subsection.text: All sales of coins issued under this Act shall include a surcharge as follows:

paragraph.text: A surcharge of $35 per coin for the $5 gold coin.
A surcharge of $10 per coin for the $1 silver coin.

subsection.text: Subject to section 5134(f)(1) of title 31, United States Code, all surcharges received by the Secretary from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be promptly paid by the Secretary to the General Society of Mayflower Descendants for educational purposes.

The General Society of Mayflower Descendants shall be subject to the audit requirements of section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code, with regard to the amounts received under subsection (b).

Notwithstanding subsection (a), no surcharge may be included with respect to the issuance under this Act of any coin during a calendar year if, as of the time of such issuance, the issuance of such coin would result in the number of commemorative coin programs issued during such year to exceed the annual 2 commemorative coin program issuance limitation under section 5112(m)(1) of title 31, United States Code (as in effect on the date of the enactment of this Act). The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to carry out this subsection.

section.text: The Secretary shall take such actions as may be necessary to ensure that—

paragraph.text: minting and issuing coins under this Act will not result in any net cost to the United States Government; and

no funds, including applicable surcharges, shall be disbursed to any recipient designated in section 7 until the total cost of designing and issuing all of the coins authorized by this Act (including labor, materials, dies, use of machinery, overhead expenses, marketing, and shipping) is recovered by the United States Treasury, consistent with sections 5112(m) and 5134(f) of title 31, United States Code.
